Home.title: Magnitude
Home.description: Magnitude is the unit of measurement, brightness of a star is measured. The lower the magnitude, the brighter the star is. Each magnitude is 2.512 brighter than the next magnitude. For example magnitude 1 is 2.512x brighter than magnitude 2.
Home.caption: Magnitude

Home.title: Apparent vs Absolute Magnitude
Home.description: Apparent magnitude is how bright the star is viewed from Earth, while Absolute magnitude is how bright the star would be, if it was 10 parsecs away from Earth.
Home.caption: Apparent vs Absolute Magnitude

Home.title: The Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram
Home.description: The Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram (HR Diagram) plots stars using their absolute magnitude against their colour/temperature. The diagram identifies a starâ€™s stage of life using its temperature and absolute magnitude.
Home.caption: The Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram

Timeline.title: Nebula
Timeline.description: Beginning of the Life cycle of a Star is a Nebula. A Nebula is a large cloud of gas and dust that is primarily made up of Hydrogen.

Timeline.title: Protostar
Timeline.description: The Nebula clumps together and starts to undergo nuclear fusion, fusing hydrogen molecules into helium, generating energy.

Timeline.title: Main sequence Star
Timeline.description: The main sequence is the stage, that the sun is at. The star continues to undergo nuclear fusion.

Timeline.title: Red Giant
Timeline.description: Once all the Hydrogen molecules have been fused together to form Helium molecules, the star will begin to expand. The star will also begin to cool.

Timeline.title: Fusion of Helium
Timeline.description: Helium begins to fuse together to form Carbon. Depending on the mass of the star, the star will either turn into a White Dwarf (6a) or a Supernova (6b)

Timeline.title: White dwarf
Timeline.description: For a star with less than 8 solar masses, the red giant core will shrink and the outer shells will blast away, forming a White Dwarf. Which will eventually cool to become a Black Dwarf.

Timeline.title: Supernova
Timeline.description: For a massive star with more than 8 solar masses, the red giant will continue to grow until it explodes violently, depending on the mass, causing it to either form a black hole (7b) or a neutron star (7a)

Timeline.title: Neutron Star
Timeline.description: Neutron Stars are stars after a supernova with extremely dense cores.

Timeline.title: Black Hole
Timeline.description: Big enough stars will eventually form a black hole. Black holes gravity is strong enough that light cannot escape it.
